"Great, just what I needed today," I muttered, staring at the blank screen where our project's progress should be glowing. I couldn't shake off the feeling that this was a disaster waiting to happen. Not just for our project, but for me too. What if I couldn't fix it? What if my team lead found out I'd been left holding the bag while she was away? I could already feel the tension between us stretching thinner than ever, like an elastic band ready to snap.

But there was no time for what-ifs. Not with this looming deadline bearing down on us like a freight train. I had to focus, had to find that needle in the haystack of code that would make everything right again.

I didn't notice the emails from other team members offering help, or the quiet tap on my shoulder from our intern asking if he could assist. All I saw were those red error messages, blinking accusingly at me like a pair of angry eyes. It was just me against them now, and I refused to lose.
